variant.question: What is measured by the sensors of an electronic torquemeter system in aeroplanes or helicopters?

options.text: The twist in the output shaft of the engine.
The angular speed of the propeller or the angular speed of the rotor.
The gearbox oil pressure.
The torsion of the propeller blades or the torsion of the rotor blades.

variant.question: The float type fuel quantity measurement system is calibrated in:

options.text: volume units and the indication varies with the temperature of the fuel.
volume units and the indication does not vary with the temperature of the fuel.
mass units and the result that the indication does not vary with the temperature of the fuel.
mass units and the indication varies with the temperature of the fuel.

variant.question: The resonant frequency of tank circuits...

options.text: Depends on the values of inductance and capacitance in the circuit.
Is independent from the values of inductance and capacitance in the circuit.
Depends only on the value of inductance in the circuit.
Depends only on the value of capacitance in the circuit.

variant.question: If the tanks of your airplane only contain water, the capacitor gauges indicate

options.text: a mass of water different from zero, but inaccurate.
the exact mass of water contained in the tanks.
a mass equal to the mass of a same volume of fuel.
a mass equal to zero.

variant.question:
The advantages of float type fuel gauge are/is:
1) easy construction.
2) independence of indications with regard to airplane attitude.
3) independence of indications with regard to the accelerations.
4) independence of indications with regard to temperature variations.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

Refer to figure. 
 The fuel tank is currently half full. The pilot request that the aircraft is refuelled to obtain 70% full tank. What is the amount of fuel that must be uplifted to obtain that value?
Concerning a fuel gauge system, a pilot is more interested in the

options.text: mass of the fuel than the volume of the fuel.
volume of the fuel than the mass of the fuel.
volume of the fuel than the permittivity of the fuel.
volume of the fuel than the density of the fuel.

variant.question: The basic principle of a capacitance fuel gauge system is that the

options.text: capacitance of a capacitor depends on the nature of the dielectric in which it is immersed.
electromotive force of a capacitor depends on the nature of the dielectric in which it is immersed.
capacitance of a capacitor only depends on the density of the liquid on which it is immersed.
internal resistance of a capacitor depends on the nature of the dielectric in which it is immersed.

variant.question: A change in temperature of the fuel inside an aircraft fuel tank affects the fuel density, volume and dielectric value (Er). An increase in temperature will result in:

options.text: an increase in volume, decrease in density and decrease in Er.
an increase in volume, increase in density and increase in Er.
a decrease in volume, increase in density and increase in Er.
a decrease in volume, decrease in density and decrease in Er.

variant.question: Capacitance measurement is based on the variation of the:

options.text: dielectric of the capacitor.
plate surface of the capacitor.
distance between the plates.
permeability of the capacitor.

variant.question:
Which of these statements concerning the fuel quantity measurement are correct or incorrect?
1) The quantity of fuel can be measured by volume.
2) The quantity of fuel can be measured by mass.

options.text: 1) correct; 2) is correct
1) correct; 2) is incorrect
1) incorrect; 2) is incorrect
1) incorrect; 2) is correct

options.text: remain the same.
increase by 5%.
increase by 10%.
decrease by 5%.

variant.question: In a compensated capacitance type quantity indicating system, the contents gauge of a half-full fuel tank indicates a fuel mass of 8000 kg. If a temperature rise increased the volume of fuel by 5%, the indicated fuel mass would:

options.text: remain the same.
decrease by 5%.
increase by 5%.
increase by 10%.

options.text: remain the same.
increase by 10%.
increase by 5%.
decrease by 5%.

permittivity.
density.

variant.question:
The disadvantages of a float type fuel gauge are
1) the design is complex.
2) the indications are influenced by the airplane attitude variations.
3) the indications are influenced by the accelerations.
4) the indications are influenced by temperature variations.The combination regrouping all the correct statements is

(Refer to the question image)
A pilot requests that the aircraft he/she is to fly is refuelled so that the total fuel on board is 70 US gal. Looking at the systems display from the annex, has the aircraft been adequately refuelled?

options.text: Yes, the amount of fuel on board is about 72 US gal.
No, the fuel indicator shows that there are 272 US gal of fuel on board.
No, the amount of fuel on board is only 50 US gal.
No, the fuel indicator shows that there are only 272 lb of fuel on board.

variant.question: The capacity fuel gauges provide information:

options.text: on mass whose indication is independent of the temperature of the fuel.
on mass whose indication varies with the temperature of the fuel.
which is independent of the temperature of the fuel.
which varies with the temperature of the fuel.

variant.question: Which of the following indication is provided by the capacitive fuel quantity measurement system?

options.text: Fuel mass.
Fuel inductance.
Fuel density-volume.
Fuel volume.

variant.question: The gauge indicating the quantity of fuel measured by a capacity gauging system can be graduated directly in weight units because the dielectric constant of fuel is:

options.text: twice that of air and varies directly with density.
the same as that of air and varies inversely with density.
the same as that of air and varies directly with density.
twice that of air and varies inversely with density.

variant.question: The principle of capacitance fuel gauges is based on the:

options.text: capacitance variation of a given capacitor with the type of dielectric.
capacitance variation by the volume measurement carried out on the sensor.
current variation in the Wheatstone bridge.
flow rate and torque variation occurring in a supply line.

variant.question: Which indication would you expect from a capacitance type fuel indication system in case of failure?

options.text: A sudden full deflection of the fuel gauge towards empty.
A progressive deflection of the gauge to full.
A frozen fuel level indication.
A yellow flag in the gauge.

variant.question: A capacitance-type fuel quantity measurement system provides the indication of the...

options.text: mass of the fuel.
density-volume of the fuel.
inductivity of the fuel.
volume of the fuel.

variant.question: Changes in temperature of the fuel affect its density, volume and dielectric value Er. A decrease in temperature causes:

options.text: a decreases in volume, increases in density and increases in Er.
an increases in volume, increases in density and increases in Er.
an increases in volume, decreases in density and decreases in Er.
a decreases in volume, decreases in density and decreases in Er.

variant.question: If the temperature rises, what will happen to the fuel in the tank?

options.text: volume of the fuel increases, density decreases, and dielectric constant Kr decreases
volume of the fuel decreases, density increases, and dielectric constant Kr increases
volume of the fuel increases, density decreases, and dielectric constant Kr remains the same
volume of the fuel increases, density increases, and dielectric constant Kr decreases

variant.question: Having refuelled an aircraft, what safety-based action(s) must be carried out?

options.text: Compare the indicated contents of the tanks with the expected contents.
Calculate the fuel consumption.
Reset the fuel gauge and load the passengers and the baggage, plus any cargo.
When refuelling is completed, switch the beacon "OFF", if the APU is NOT running.

variant.question:
Given the following parameters, in a capacitance fuel gauge, the correct formula is: 
(A = area of plates, D = distance between plates, E = dielectric permittivity)

options.text: Capacitance = E x A / D
Capacitance = A x D / E
Capacitance = E x D / A
Capacitance = E x D x A

variant.question: What shall you do in case of loss of all fuel indications?

options.text: Pull and reset the circuit breaker to check if the system restarts, unless checklists says otherwise.
Turn off all the fuel pumps.
Turn on cross-feed valve.
Initiate a diversion immediately.

variant.question: The principle of capacity gauges is based on the capacitance variation of:

options.text: a capacitor with the type of dielectric.
two dissimilar metals joined together at their ends.
liquids with the variations in temperature.
two dissimilar metals joined together at one end only.

2. accelerations

That the fuel temperature is within acceptable limits.
That the fuel type is correctly recorded.
That the fuel in the tanks is the correct type/grade.

indications are influenced by aircraft attitude variations, accelerations, and temperature variations, and the complex design.
design is complex.

indications are influenced by aircraft attitude variations, accelerations, and temperature variations, and the complex design.
design is complex.

variant.question: What safety action must be performed after refueling?

options.text: The indicated value of the fuel must be compared to the calculated fuel content.
The fuel must be reset after refueling.
The fuel slip needs to be handled to the refueling personnel.
Only afterwards, the passengers can be embarked, and their luggage and cargo loaded.

variant.question: After refueling procedure, you the pilot notices that the amount of fuel in the tanks differs significantly with what you are expecting. It seems to be in the order of 2 900 kg more fuel than needed for the intended flight. Which statement is correct?

options.text: Performance calculations must be redone, and aircraft and runway conditions must be within limits in order for the flight to safely continue.
You can never have too much fuel.
Check that the zero fuel mass is within limits and carry on with the operation.
Defueling procedure must always be performed in this case

options.text: Farrads
Watts
Joules
Volts

variant.question: Convert 430 ft/min to m/s...
Convert 800 ft/min to m/s...

options.text: 12 m/s

variant.question: After the pilot has set up the FMS and inserted an initial fuel quantity, the aircraft is still being refuelled. After refuelling, there's a big difference between the actual fuel and the fuel quantity inserted into the FMS. Which option is correct?

options.text: The calculations for the flight will be wrong and can only be corrected by re-initialising the FMS.
A significant difference between the measured and inserted values will trigger an error caption.
Since the fuel quantity is critical data, the FMS computer will freeze and stop to calculate VNAV and LNAV data and must be reset.
There is NO problem as the inserted quantity will be automatically updated to the actual value.
